conversation:
Gale: Nothing a bit of magic can't solve.
Gale: You see, I have this... condition. Very different from the parasite we share, but just as deadly.
Player: What kind of condition?
Gale: The specifics are rather personal, but suffice it to say that it is a malady I have learned to live with - though not without some effort.
Gale: What it comes down to is this: every so often I need to get my hands on a powerful magical item and absorb the Weave inside.
Player: What kind of items are we talking about exactly?
Gale: Staffs, tomes, cowls - the form doesn't matter, so long as it's brimming with Weave.
Gale: Catastrophe.
Gale: It's been days since I last consumed an artefact - since before we were abducted. It's only a matter of time before my craving returns.
Gale: That is why I turn to you. I need you to help me find magic items to consume. It is vital. Dare I say it, critical.
Player: Where do you suggest we find the artefacts you need?
Gale: As luck would have it, Faerûn is full of them, though I do feel obliged to point out that items of power tend to be in the hands of the powerful.
Gale: There will be danger involved - or great cost.
Player: And at the end of all that I lose a valuable artefact? No thanks.
Gale: I know that what I ask may seem unreasonable, but I promise I only make such a request because it is so incredibly important.
Gale: Please - trust me. Your help could be the difference between life and death.
Player: Use your tadpole. Seek the danger at the heart of Gale's request.
: False
Gale: I'm afraid that's not going to work on me. Look, I appreciate your curiosity, but don't pursue this path.
Gale: Let us agree on actions first and explanations later. Yes?
Player: Sorry - that's not going work for me. I need an explanation.
Gale: I understand that I'm asking for a lot, but I can't tell you everything. Not yet anyway.
Gale: Please reconsider.
Player: You aren't going to drop this, are you?
Gale: No.
Player: Neither am I. We'll have to see who gives up first.
Gale: Very well. You're clearly in no mood to be receptive to my request at present.

Gale: Why don't we take a little break? Allow ourselves a few moments of rest. Gives me a chance to talk to you about something, well, rather important.
Player: 'Rather important' no less? All right, go ahead.
Gale: We've been on the road together for a while now, haven't we? Survived some perils, overcame some obstacles.
Gale: Ever since you were kind enough to free me from that stone, I've seen you demonstrate remarkable guile and courage.
Gale: The way you defused the tension between Zevlor and Aradin.
Gale: The way you stood in front of a crossbow to prevent a murder.
Gale: The way you got Kagha to release the girl.
Gale: The way you handled Nettie when she poisoned you.
Gale: The way you got that boy out of a harpy's clutches.
Gale: The way you followed the protocol and brought me back to life.
Gale: These deeds attest to a strong and noble character. They attest to prime leadership qualities as well.
Gale: In short: I've grown to trust you.
Player: Enough with the flattery. Where is this going?
Gale: I was being quite sincere, I assure you.
Gale: The reason I make a point of saying this is that I've grown confident enough to tell you something I've yet to tell another living soul. Except for my cat.
Gale: You see, I have this... condition. Very different from the parasite we share, but just as deadly.
Player: What kind of condition?
Gale: The specifics are rather personal, but suffice it to say that it is a malady I have learned to live with - though not without some effort.
Gale: What it comes down to is this: every so often I need to get my hands on a powerful magical item and absorb the Weave inside.
Player: Wouldn't that ruin the item?
Gale: Trust me when I say - the loss of the occasional wizard's staff or tome of enchantment is a bargain given the cost of allowing me to deteriorate.
Gale: Catastrophe.
Gale: It's been days since I last consumed an artefact - since before we were abducted. It's only a matter of time before my craving returns.
Gale: That is why I turn to you. I need you to help me find magic items to consume. It is vital. Dare I say it, critical.
Player: Where do you suggest we find the artefacts you need?
Gale: As luck would have it, Faerûn is full of them, though I do feel obliged to point out that items of power tend to be in the hands of the powerful.
Gale: There will be danger involved - or great cost.
Player: And at the end of all that I lose a valuable artefact? No thanks.
Gale: I know that what I ask may seem unreasonable, but I promise I only make such a request because it is so incredibly important.
Gale: Please - trust me. Your help could be the difference between life and death.

: True
Narrator: *You become one with Gale's mind and you can feel something sinister oppressing you.*
Narrator: *It's... inside of you, a mighty darkness radiating from your chest.*
Narrator: *You could try to push further, but your hold over Gale feels brittle. It won't be easy delving deeper without him noticing.*
Player: Decide not to risk it.
Gale: So? Do you agree?
Player: No. I do not.
Player: Neither am I. We'll have to see who gives up first.
Gale: Very well. You're clearly in no mood to be receptive to my request at present.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Let's not let an ancient squabble interfere with the task at hand.
Isobel: Not as ancient as you think.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selûnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
: False
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him.
Isobel: A True Soul with a soul. Imagine.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selûnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Silently petition Lady Shar for guidance.
Narrator: *She offers you nothing.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: There's more to it than that. The figure I saw: she means something to you.
: True
Gale: She does. She's... She's Mystra.
Gale: I can't quite describe it, the need I sometimes feel to see her - to draw the filaments of fantasy into existence.
Gale: No sculpture or painting could ever do her justice, only the fabric that she herself is and embodies:
Gale: The Weave.
Gale: Mystra is all magic. And as far as I'm concerned, she is all creation.
Player: I quite agree. There's no greater deity than Mystra.
Gale: I see you understand.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it.
Gale: It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses.
Gale: Would you like to experience this?
Player: Mystra normally answers me through prayer, but I don't mind trying.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture with ease.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player imitates the gesture. There’s a first visual effect. Some sparks of magic start to appear around the player and Gale.
Narrator: *A familiar feeling - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: Belt the words with a little flourish on 'Ao'.
: True
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The visual effect intensifies. There’s the start of a glow, of a rush of beautiful magic.
Narrator: *Ah, yes: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Harmony comes easily to you. Allow it to wash over your mind and magic.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.*
Narrator: *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.*
Narrator: *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: You're a good teacher.
Gale: I know.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture kicking him in the gut.

Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: A True Soul in such a grotesque form? The Absolute has a place in Her heart even for darthiir.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.

Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Narrator: *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*

Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.*
Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...*
Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I prefer to face my enemies rather than stabbing them in the back.
Nightwarden Minthara: How noble. I prefer to win.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: It shall be so.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.

Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: If you say so.
Gale: I do - because it's through practice that I seek to perfect. To augment.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it.
Gale: It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses.
Gale: That is why I asked you to seek me out, to offer you a taste of such wonders. Would you like me to show you?
Gale: Would you like to experience this?
Player: I'd be glad to try, though I normally commune with Mystra through prayer.
Gale: Then follow my lead.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selûnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Try to understand what's happening.
Narrator: *Is Lady Shar punishing you? Or perhaps testing you? Is it the tadpole, or a curse? You cannot say.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm cursed with spells of madness, forgive me what I said.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you?
Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*

Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you?
Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?

Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm not going to follow my order. You will live.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you?
Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: I am going to save these lands. I- I mean you no harm.
Isobel: You'd be a bit late to the party if you did. Ketheric Thorm done for. Or didn't you see that angel carving a path straight toward Moonrise Towers?
Player: Attack her. The Urge aches for it.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: If you say so.
Gale: I do - because it's through practice that I seek to perfect. To augment.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it.
Gale: It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses.
Gale: That is why I asked you to seek me out, to offer you a taste of such wonders. Would you like me to show you?
Gale: Would you like to experience this?
Player: Magic normally comes to me through prayer, but I don't mind trying.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture slowly and as precisely as you can.
: True
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: An easy incantation. Simply repeat after Gale.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The visual effect intensifies. There’s the start of a glow, of a rush of beautiful magic.
Narrator: *Ah, yes: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Recede into the calm centre of your mind, just like you were taught at the academy.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.*
Narrator: *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: I thought I smelled a Selûnite.
Isobel: At your service.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul, sister? It is good to have your assistance.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I don't have the most trustworthy face.
Nightwarden Minthara: They're half-devil refugees... Nobody wants them.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drowning creature will cling to a blade if nothing else is offered. Be that blade.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: They'll die thinking I'm their hero.
Nightwarden Minthara: Exquisite. The Absolute chose well when She chose you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: If you say so.
Gale: I do - because it's through practice that I seek to perfect. To augment.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it.
Gale: It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses.
Gale: That is why I asked you to seek me out, to offer you a taste of such wonders. Would you like me to show you?
Gale: Would you like to experience this?
Player: Yes, I would.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture with a flourish.
: True
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: You sense power in these words. Speak them deliberately.
: True
Narrator: *Suddenly: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Picture a place of utter peace, away from all harm and the mayhem of civilisation.
Player: Picture the perfect darkness - to be in the womb of Shar.
: True
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the presence of a woman, the woman who hovered over Gale's palm.*
Narrator: *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.*
Narrator: *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: It's not quite like praying to her. She feels closer, somehow.
Gale: Quite so. The Weave is a sensitive conduit.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture kicking him in the gut.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Let's not let an ancient squabble interfere with the task at hand.
Isobel: Not as ancient as you think.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selûne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Narrator: *Suddenly: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Sink deep into your magic. It is who you are. It is home.

Isobel: On with you. Unless you want to come back to a gaggle of shadow-cursed Harpers.

Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.

Player: Chase away your putrid desires.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Let's not let an ancient squabble interfere with the task at hand.
Isobel: Not as ancient as you think.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I may have the parasite of a True Soul, but not the mind of one.
Isobel: And that's what makes you essential.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Selûnite.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: There's more to it than that. The figure I saw: she means something to you.
: True
Gale: She does. She's... She's Mystra.
Gale: I can't quite describe it, the need I sometimes feel to see her - to draw the filaments of fantasy into existence.
Gale: No sculpture or painting could ever do her justice, only the fabric that she herself is and embodies:
Gale: The Weave.
Gale: Mystra is all magic. And as far as I'm concerned, she is all creation.
Player: I didn't realise the depth of your devotion.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it.
Gale: It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses.
Gale: Would you like to experience this?
Player: Mystra normally answers me through prayer, but I don't mind trying.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture with ease.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player imitates the gesture. There’s a first visual effect. Some sparks of magic start to appear around the player and Gale.
Narrator: *A familiar feeling - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: An easy incantation. Simply repeat after Gale.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul? Little wonder that you serve me so well.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Narrator: *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: Perhaps you can misdirect her... or kill her.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.*
Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...*
Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: You're right. I'll see you at the grove.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
: True
Narrator: *Her breath catches; you notice a barely-perceptible shudder run through her body.*
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him.
Isobel: A True Soul with a soul. Imagine.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selûnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selûne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.

Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: A True Soul in such a grotesque form? The Absolute has a place in Her heart even for darthiir.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Narrator: *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: The grove's inhabitants are weak - it's ready to fall.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.*
Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Allow her to read your thoughts.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...*
Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: There's more to it than that. The figure I saw: she means something to you.
: True
Gale: She does. She's... She's Mystra.
Gale: I can't quite describe it, the need I sometimes feel to see her - to draw the filaments of fantasy into existence.
Gale: No sculpture or painting could ever do her justice, only the fabric that she herself is and embodies:
Gale: The Weave.
Gale: Mystra is all magic. And as far as I'm concerned, she is all creation.
Player: I didn't realise the depth of your devotion.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it.
Gale: It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses.
Gale: Would you like to experience this?
Player: Yes, I would.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture with ease.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player imitates the gesture. There’s a first visual effect. Some sparks of magic start to appear around the player and Gale.
Narrator: *A familiar feeling - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: Repeat the words, slowly, but carefully.
Player: You sense power in these words. Speak them deliberately.
: True
Narrator: *Suddenly: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Sink deep into your magic. It is who you are. It is home.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.*
Narrator: *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.*
Narrator: *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: The same as it always does.
Gale: You're hard to please, aren't you?
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture his severed head on a spike.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale holds out his arm. Above the palm of his hand is conjured in gold-coloured magic the image of a woman, the goddess Mystra. He's looking at the figure intensely.
Player: Pretty.
Gale: Oh! My, you startled me. I... I was miles away.
NodeContext: Gale is looking at a miniature magical projection of Mystra he's created in his hand in his hand. Startled, he dispells it.
Player: Is everything all right?
Gale: Of course, of course. I was just... practising an incantation.
Player: There's more to it than that. The figure I saw: she means something to you.
: True
Gale: She does. She's... She's Mystra.
Gale: I can't quite describe it, the need I sometimes feel to see her - to draw the filaments of fantasy into existence.
Gale: No sculpture or painting could ever do her justice, only the fabric that she herself is and embodies:
Gale: The Weave.
Gale: Mystra is all magic. And as far as I'm concerned, she is all creation.
Player: I didn't realise the depth of your devotion.
Gale: Magic is... my life. I've been in touch with the Weave for as long as I can remember. There's nothing like it.
Gale: It's like music, poetry, physical beauty all rolled into one and given expression through the senses.
Gale: Would you like to experience this?
Player: Mystra normally answers me through prayer, but I don't mind trying.
Gale: Then follow my lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Gale walks around behind the player (as though teaching them to fly a kite) and makes a delicate gesture with both hands.
Gale: Now you.
Player: Imitate the gesture quickly and decisively.
: True
Narrator: *You feel something strange - like a kind word and a kind touch at the same time. It's warm and comfortable.*
Gale: Excellent. Now repeat after me: Ah-Thran Mystra-Ryl Kantrach-Ao.
Player: You sense power in these words. Speak them deliberately.
: True
Narrator: *Suddenly: the scent of rosewater and a sense of wellbeing. A sliver of Weave that tastes sweet on the tongue.*
Gale: Very good. Now I want you to picture in your mind the concept of harmony. As true as you can.
Player: Recede into the calm centre of your mind, just like you were taught at the academy.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player and Gale are now fully enveloped in a magic glow - a protective field of beautiful magic. Unconsciously player steps back closer to Gale.
Narrator: *You see - or is it sense? - the unmistakable presence of Mystra, the Lady of Mysteries.*
Narrator: *There's something like the anticipation of a kiss, then the pleasure of being cloaked in peace.*
Narrator: *You are safe. You are nestled in the cup of her hand.*
Gale: You did it. You're channelling the Weave. How does it feel?
Player: Magical.
Gale: That it does.
Narrator: *The Weave connects you. The moment feels intimate.*
Player: Hold on to the moment. It's a good night for intimacy.
Narrator: *You realise the Weave is making you one. You have but to imagine your desire, and Gale will know it.*
Player: Picture kicking him in the gut.

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul? Little wonder that you serve me so well.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
Narrator: *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: Leading her to the tieflings might doom them... but it would earn her trust.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin.
Nightwarden Minthara: Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.*
Narrator: *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...*
Narrator: *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selûnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selûnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Narrator: *Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her. Dooming the village would bring foul glory. You can almost taste it.*
Narrator: *This is the one Sceleritas sent you to kill. Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her.*
Isobel: On with you. Unless you want to come back to a gaggle of shadow-cursed Harpers.
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
: True
Narrator: *Her breath catches; you notice a barely-perceptible shudder run through her body.*
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him.
Isobel: A True Soul with a soul. Imagine.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I may have the parasite of a True Soul, but not the mind of one.
Isobel: And that's what makes you essential.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Isobel: On with you. Unless you want to come back to a gaggle of shadow-cursed Harpers.
Player: I won't let that happen.
Isobel: I know you won't.
Isobel: Don't let Jaheira catch you dawdling.
Narrator: *There is something about her... it would be wonderful to kill her. A perfect tragedy.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selûnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: You're right. I'll see you at the grove.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: I got myself nabbed though; ended up all snug in a cage instead of smashed. I'm wily like that.
Sazza: And then the Absolute answered my prayers - sent a True Soul to save me!
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: All right. Expect me at the grove.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: It's breathtaking, Gale. Is this starry sky your doing?
Gale: Indeed. The curse is still present of course - just veiled and at arm's length for now. Not a trick I can repeat often, but tonight? Tonight is different.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Are you not afraid?
Gale: Afraid? No, I am terrified. But fear or courage or reason cannot change the charge I've been given.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You sound sure in your course of action then.
Gale: Resigned to it, rather. But that is not to say I am without fear. Far from it.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: She's telling the truth. She didn't know.
Sazza: I told ya! I was tryin' to follow orders best I could!
Nightwarden Minthara: Silence, wretch. And remember - you owe your miserable life to this one.
Sazza: I won't cause any more trouble - I swears it.
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: All right. Expect me at the grove.

Shadowheart: Enough. I don't answer to you. Not anymore. I'm here for my family.

Viconia DeVir: Curious, have you had a chance of heart? Or forgotten our little agreement? Turn this wayward child over to me, and you shall go free, with Lady Shar's faithful as your allies.
NodeContext: Addressed to GROUP_Players rather than SH. Referring to an earlier agreement they made to betray SH.
Viconia DeVir: You there - remember our agreement? Surrender her to me, now, and you can consider Lady Shar's forces your allies in the battles to come.
Player: She's all yours.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.

Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
: False
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Player: And I'll drink to the darkness that will soon fall when I drag Isobel all the way to Moonrise Towers.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.
Jaheira: The light is rather dim, out here in the shadowlands. The point remains:
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
