Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: How thoughtful. And where did you find this friend?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: Keep quiet.
Sazza: You coulda told me who you woz!
Sazza: Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I'll get it done.

Orin: Loosen the bonds, sweet meat. Bhaal does not crave the taste of bait on his altar.
NodeContext: Mocking the player  for saving their companion - it was never about them
Orin: No trust in my promises, but I smell the tyrant's corpse-reek. You are steeped in his rot.
Orin: See how good I was? How patient while you drained the tyrant's juices for me?
Orin: But you did not listen. Thought my instructions could be ignored. I told you what to do, whelp worm, and you disobeyed.
Orin: Disobedience must be punished.
NodeContext: Whispered to the comapnion on the altar, but intended for the player. She's been punished for her own disobedience countless times before, and enjoys doling this out to others.
Orin: Did it think it could protect? Did it think it could save? Only the blades can offer salvation.
NodeContext: Hushed, as though to companion on altar, but really for player's benefit. Mocking player's intentions. On  the cusp of killing the victim. 'It' is player.
Player: His fate is of no interest to me.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But she's worthless to you!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1)

Player: Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

Orin: Look, your saviour approaches.

NodeContext: Fighting temptation to just kill the victim anyway, trying to stress the player out
GROUP_ORI_DU: Kill him. He is nothing to me.

Fist Marcus: Hello, Isobel.
InternalNodeContext: Marcus never vouched for the players. This is their first encounter with him.
Isobel: Marcus - is that you? What's happened to you?
Fist Marcus: I've been blessed. You can be too. Come with me and you can hear it all from Ketheric himself.
Player: I say we follow the winged freak.
Isobel: It would be your doom. And mine.
Fist Marcus: True Soul. My instructions are clear: take the girl to Ketheric. Alive.
Player: What does he want with her?
Isobel: What's going on? If you have something to say, say it.
Player: You're going to meet Ketheric - face-to-face.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: Why did you summon me here?
Gale: I wanted to see you. While I still could.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Is this truly what you want, to die for the promise of Mystra's forgiveness?
Gale: Babe or crone, coward or hero, death is assured. Mystra's forgiveness is not. If you knew the end was near, would you not want to ensure it had meaning?
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You sound sure in your course of action then.
Gale: Resigned to it, rather. But that is not to say I am without fear. Far from it.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: Why did you summon me here?
Gale: I wanted to see you. While I still could.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: It's a heavy burden, yes - but one you're able for. Think of the good your sacrifice will do.
Gale: I am trying. Believe me, I am. The path is set, and I will not stray from it - even as my heart quakes.
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: Nothing is inevitable. Not when we face it together. You don't have to die.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Gale: Please - this has gone on long enough.
Gale: There's something I've been trying to tell you - I have a condition that requires me to consume potent magical artefacts.
Gale: I'm afraid my condition has worsened to the point I cannot in good conscience stay in this company of ours. I need to leave, and seek an item to consume before it's too late.
Player: Bye then.

Fist Marcus: Hello, Isobel.
InternalNodeContext: Marcus never vouched for the players. This is their first encounter with him.
Isobel: Marcus - is that you? What's happened to you?
Fist Marcus: I've been blessed. You can be too. Come with me and you can hear it all from Ketheric himself.
Player: I say we follow the winged freak.
Isobel: It would be your doom. And mine.
Fist Marcus: True Soul. My instructions are clear: take the girl to Ketheric. Alive.
Player: Probe his thoughts for more information.
: True
Narrator: *A haunting face swims into your mind's eye, its instructions vivid in your mind: nothing is more important than bringing the girl - alive.*
Isobel: What's going on? If you have something to say, say it.
Player: You're going to meet Ketheric - face-to-face.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: She's telling the truth. She didn't know.
Sazza: I told ya! I was tryin' to follow orders best I could!
Nightwarden Minthara: Silence, wretch. And remember - you owe your miserable life to this one.
Sazza: I won't cause any more trouble - I swears it.
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I'll get it done.

Viconia DeVir: They already heard how you disgraced yourself before Lady Shar. How she marked you as the enemy. But it is quite another thing for them to see it for themselves.
Viconia DeVir: I am very glad you decided to return. A cautionary tale such as yours will be studied by Lady Shar's initiates for years to come.
Viconia DeVir: But perhaps I can make a case for some small measure of mercy. Give me the artefact, and I can at least make this quick.
Shadowheart: Enough. I don't answer to you. Not anymore. I'm here for my family.
Shadowheart: That's right. I know what you did. And it's not going to be quick - not for you.
Viconia DeVir: This is your family. And now you have turned your back on it.
NodeContext: Small sweep of her right hand at the general surrounds. Referring to the onlooking Shar worshippers
Viconia DeVir: The artefact was your last chance to prove yourself - and you squandered it.
Player: Why is the artefact so important to you?
Player: I've heard enough.
Shadowheart: Likewise.
Player: Keep silent.
Viconia DeVir: You there - surrender this one to me, now, and you can consider Lady Shar's forces your allies in the battles to come.
Player: She's all yours.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: Hah! This should be good.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: If you're gloating now, just wait 'til you hear my offer, petal.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: I can give you power. Anything you want!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Just let me go. (Ability Score +1)
Astarion: I'm all for killing her, but let's get that power first, hmm?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: What'll it be, petal?
Player: Give me power - the more, the better.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.
Jaheira: The light is rather dim, out here in the shadowlands. The point remains:
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
: False
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers.
Jaheira: To your very good health.
Player: Jaheira, there's something you need to know: Marcus is a True Soul, and he's planning to kidnap Isobel.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.

: False

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: Why did you summon me here?
Gale: I wanted to see you. While I still could.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: You speak as if this affects you alone. How many will die if you unleash what's inside you?
Gale: Fewer than if the Absolute goes unchecked. I don't want to kill, and I don't want to die... but inaction will lead to bloodshed all the same.
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You sound sure in your course of action then.
Gale: Resigned to it, rather. But that is not to say I am without fear. Far from it.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
: False
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Player: Jaheira, there's something you need to know: Marcus is a True Soul, and he's planning to kidnap Isobel.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: I have proof, if you'll just come upstairs and look.
: False
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers.
Jaheira: To your very good health.
Player: And I'll drink to the darkness that will soon fall when I drag Isobel all the way to Moonrise Towers.

Orin: Look, your saviour approaches.
NodeContext: Hushed, as though to companion on altar, but really for player's benefit. Mocking reassurance

Orin: I said I'd leave the blood inside. But it smells sweet, and the blade was made to slice...
NodeContext: Fighting temptation to just kill the victim anyway, trying to stress the player out
GROUP_ORI_DU: Kill her. She is nothing to me.

Zevlor: This is it. Everything turns on this.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The archer nocks another arrow, when the army arrives beneath Minthara and lowers the bow to watch
Asharak: Get that damn gate closed!
Asharak: This is it, people. Weapons ready, eyes to the front.
Asharak: Anyone who takes down a worg gets their choice of cut tonight...
Asharak: By Amaunator's Eternal Sun, none of us are dying today!
Narrator: *A splinter of ice works its way into your mind.*
Nightwarden Minthara: A pretty speech. It almost brings a tear to my eye.
NodeContext: amused, referring to the tiefling leaders inspiring speech to the defenders but talking to the player
Nightwarden Minthara: Now slit his throat, and open that gate. The Absolute wants all of them dead.
NodeContext: simple, to the point - killing is a very ordinary thing to her
Player: Of course - as does my god.

Gauntlet Edwynna: No refugees. It is decreed.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Halt! By orders of Lord Gortash, refugees are no longer allowed in the city. Turn around.
Player: I have urgent business in the city.
Player: I'm not a refugee.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Well, do you have the means to support yourself? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: I can take care of myself. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Gauntlet Edwynna: Right. Article 30.1.5 of the Council's Decree on Extraordinary Wartime Measures. I am confiscating that. The city thanks you for your contribution.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Your name?
Player: I'm called Daisy Dewdrop Fluffington.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Well met, citizen Fluffington.
Narrator: *Your parasite stirs. From the construct, you feel connection. Resonance.*
Player: Can I go now?
Gauntlet Edwynna: Not just yet.
Gauntlet Edwynna: State your business.
Wyll: My good lady. I am Wyll Ravengard. My business is the city's business.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Wyll Ravengard? Of course, of course - the city is always open to you. But I'm afraid you'll still need to comply with new protocol. By Lord Gortash's command.
Player: Please, let me pass. Baldur's Gate is my city, my home.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Uh-huh. Eyes open, body still.
NodeContext: "Uh-huh" as in, "Yes, I heard you and am going with it."
Player: Do as she says. Stand still.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The steel watcher steps forward and begins to scan the player's eyes.
There is NO mindmeld, because player is NOT tadpoled.
There is NO mindmeld, because player is NOT tadpoled.
Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You may not carry a mind flayer parasite, but it sees you - knows you.*
Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.*
Narrator: *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*
Karlach: Whoa. My engine. It's almost... I don't know. Buzzing. Like it's paying attention.
Narrator: *Your party's prior transgressions are reflected in its stare, as witnessed by the cult's ever-alert scrying eyes.*
Narrator: *It has heard the howls of slaughtered goblins.*
Narrator: *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.*
Narrator: *It knows the cold walls of Moonrise Towers, and the cultists who fell there.*

Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.

Gandrel: Today? The same as you - a humble supplicant, come to bargain with the lady of this house.

Player: My business here is my own.

Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus - I believe I mentioned him before. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.
Gale: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.
Gale: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: To what end?
Gale: To every end you can imagine, and a thousand more beyond.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: You dismiss the entire pantheon so easily. Not all gods are selfish.
Gale: Some gods may delude themselves into believing they care about their worshippers, but when it comes down to it - we're all expendable. Children to be appeased, not respected.
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: I thought you were past this kind of temptation, Gale. You know exactly where such over-reaching leads.
Gale: Neither of us can know what truly may be if we don't at least try. Potential is nothing in itself - just a fleeting dream, unless we drag it into the waking world. Please, at least think on it.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: How did such a powerful object end up in the hands of the Absolute?
Gale: I haven't the foggiest. No doubt through some nefarious means - the crown's existence had been consigned to legend centuries ago.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: That Crown's caused chaos. We should be seeking a way to destroy it, not make it more powerful.
Gale: Do not mistake the crown itself for the actions of its wearer, or rather, those controlling its wearer at present.
Gale: If we could restore its former glory, it would no longer be a mere leash and collar, used to subjugate friend or foe. It would be something greater. Something divine.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Don't dare to assume why I worship. Not all of us share such transactional relationships with our gods.
Gale: But do you not expect something in return for your devotion? Some favour, some stir of courage, some response?
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: Or to destroy the next wizard who attempts it. The attempt would kill you as it killed Karsus.
Gale: Do you think I had not considered that? I have no intention of repeating his folly.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Wyll: Father's words.

Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.
Gale: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.
Gale: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: That Crown's caused chaos. We should be seeking a way to destroy it, not make it more powerful.
Gale: Do not mistake the crown itself for the actions of its wearer, or rather, those controlling its wearer at present.
Gale: If we could restore its former glory, it would no longer be a mere leash and collar, used to subjugate friend or foe. It would be something greater. Something divine.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Don't dare to assume why I worship. Not all of us share such transactional relationships with our gods.
Gale: But do you not expect something in return for your devotion? Some favour, some stir of courage, some response?
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: So you want the Crown to settle a score with Mystra?
Gale: She sent me to die.
Gale: Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars?
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: What you're suggesting is blasphemy. You'd be wise to banish these notions from your head.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Lorroakan: You have a job to do. So do it - quickly.

Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.

NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.

: True

Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.' Ulder's words. I'd almost forgotten.
Counsellor Florrick: No more sulking. I know what to do.
Counsellor Florrick: Unlock my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock.
Counsellor Florrick: I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

Sarevok Anchev: A pleasing thing, to see these stones stained with the blood of those who disgraced my Father.
Sarevok Anchev: Our Father.
Sarevok Anchev: I know my like, child of Bhaal - but I needed to see you slaughter, first. To take life and revel in it.
Sarevok Anchev: Are you here to have your vengeance on my granddaughter, Orin?
Sarevok Anchev: But now, you have returned. Tell me, are you here to have your vengeance on my granddaughter?
Player: No, Sarevok - I am here to slay you.
Sarevok Anchev: O noisome Child, it would bring waves of enlightened rapture to duel you, but it is impossible now.
Sarevok Anchev: I have already been sacrificed, centuries ago, upon Bhaal's own graven altar. I am now but a shadow of my former self.
Sarevok Anchev: Orin is the one you seek to butcher. She only seeks the Bhaalian favour you were born to inherit.
Sarevok Anchev: She may have usurped you once, but all her rites and rituals will never match her to your natural gift.
Sarevok Anchev: Bhaal is about to name a new Chosen. All is between you and my granddaughter Orin now, and Orin has much to learn.
Sarevok Anchev: Our lord does not care for beauty. Bhaal cares only for death. Death in numbers. Death in droves.
Sarevok Anchev: It is a lesson Orin will only learn in death. I wonder if you will be the one to teach her?
Player: I came here to become an Unholy Assassin, not to clean up after your offspring, Sarevok.

Sarevok Anchev: I have heard of the duel Orin proposed to you. She seeks to sacrifice you in our Father's temple.
Sarevok Anchev: She dreams that your corpse will be her masterpiece, but she forgets - before your incident, you were the true master.
Sarevok Anchev: You were murder. Pure murder. No excesses. No pretentions.
Sarevok Anchev: I believe you will be the one to slay Orin.

Sarevok Anchev: Before you may return to our Father's fold, I must first ensure that you remain as pure and worthy of his blessing as you once were.
Sarevok Anchev: Come, child of Murder, let me lead you in Bhaal's worship.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed.
Nightwarden Minthara: And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.

Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: The future you propose is shaped by violence. I'd prefer to find another way.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is violence in your future regardless. With me, you can at least be sure the violence will lead to glory.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: If you go to Baldur's Gate, you're going alone.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without you - without the Prism - I cannot risk going to the city. The Absolute would take my mind again.
Player: You can stay with me if you swear to follow my lead.
Nightwarden Minthara: Fine. All I ask of you is that you keep an open mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?

Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Vlaakith: You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.
Player: I will do as you wish.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge
Arabella: Twist'em up!

Karlach: Hey! That's Arabella. Kid from the druid's grove. That snake woman nearly did her in. Looks like she's learned a thing or two.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: How about you teach me those powers of yours?
Arabella: Mm. Maybe. But you gotta help me first.
Arabella: Me and mum and pops, we followed Zevlor out here. Then he - he -
Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.
Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm.
Arabella: Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: Your parents are dead, sorry to say.
Arabella: You lie! They're out there. And if you won't find 'em, I will!
NodeContext: Found out her parents are dead. Distraught - her sorcerous powers begin to manifest, intensifying her emotional state.
Player: People die, and that's that. You can stay in my camp, if you quit your blubbering.
: False
Arabella: To the hells with your camp, and to the hells with you.

Lunkbug: Oh Beldron... I'm so sorry. I'll get you out of there. I promise.
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?
Player: I spoke with their ghosts. Chatty folks, all in all.
Apprentice Laridda: Ghosts? N-no. That can't be. This must be a joke.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: Fear not, gnome. I will protect you. Tell me what you know.
Apprentice Laridda: I - all right. Go ahead, Lunkbug. Tell her.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Karlach: Some firepower'll help bust open that wall. Then we can free the poor lads inside.
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.
Gale: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.
Gale: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: Aren't you forgetting something? We have to hand the Crown to Raphael...
Gale: A situation I suggest we remedy with the utmost urgency.
Gale: I promise you - the power such an item would give us is worth transcending all nine Hells for. The heavens too, while we're at it.
NodeContext: Gleam in his eyes, excitement
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: And you think Mystra will let you do this?
Gale: I don't know. Ao does not look kindly on gods meddling in mortal affairs - she may have no choice but to stand by and let events unfold.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: And you believe yourself to be that successor?
Gale: Not until this moment, but I can't help beginning to see such a destiny unfold before me.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together.
Nightwarden Minthara: But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it?
Nightwarden Minthara: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: A bold gamble. How can you be sure it's possible?
Nightwarden Minthara: I would have thought this entire conspiracy of gods and monsters to be impossible if I had not seen it for myself.
Nightwarden Minthara: We may fail, but we must try.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.
Nightwarden Minthara: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: Maybe I'll change your mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: The elder brain is the only thing that has ever managed to change my mind. You're welcome to try.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To impress you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.
Gale: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.
Gale: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: We already know the crown's dangerous. Wouldn't that make things worse?
Gale: Worse? It could be the best thing that ever happened to me. To us.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: And you think Mystra will let you do this?
Gale: I don't know. Ao does not look kindly on gods meddling in mortal affairs - she may have no choice but to stand by and let events unfold.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: Or to destroy the next wizard who attempts it. The attempt would kill you as it killed Karsus.
Gale: Do you think I had not considered that? I have no intention of repeating his folly.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Are you talking about Auntie Ethel?
Gandrel: A gentle name. But I speak of her nature.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak plainly. What is she?
Gandrel: A powerful friend. A terrible foe. That, I cannot decide for you.
Gandrel: For my part - I need her knowledge. The thing I hunt has gone to ground.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Come now - I've almost certainly killed worse.
: True
Gandrel: I would not be so sure. But I won't keep the truth from you.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: We've met - he's not the type to come quietly.
Gandrel: You do know him? I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: The design for self-destruction, more like. Didn't this crown kill Karsus?
Gale: Not exactly. It was what he did with it that sealed his fate, and for a time, that of magic itself. The Crown was merely the means.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: Aren't you forgetting something? We have to hand the Crown to Raphael...
Gale: A situation I suggest we remedy with the utmost urgency.
Gale: I promise you - the power such an item would give us is worth transcending all nine Hells for. The heavens too, while we're at it.
NodeContext: Gleam in his eyes, excitement
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: And you think Mystra will let you do this?
Gale: I don't know. Ao does not look kindly on gods meddling in mortal affairs - she may have no choice but to stand by and let events unfold.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: And you believe yourself to be that successor?
Gale: Not until this moment, but I can't help beginning to see such a destiny unfold before me.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Gale: I finally have the tome I needed. Such knowledge - such power - contained in such a small object.
Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: A design you could follow?
Gale: Not from scratch - unless you happen to have several pounds of the purest Netherese metals in that pack of yours?
Gale: Don't worry - I'm not asking you to surrender anything else on my account. What's called for here is something altogether different.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: You 'think'? What happens if you fail?
Gale: Well, there'd be risk in such an endeavour, but only proportionate to the reward.
NodeContext: Doesn't want to get bogged down by doubts like these
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Mortals are far better guardians of their fates than the gods. We have more to lose.
Gale: Then you're already wiser than me. That's a lesson I've only recently learned.
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: And you believe yourself to be that successor?
Gale: Not until this moment, but I can't help beginning to see such a destiny unfold before me.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.

Alfira: And I regret it with every breath.
Alfira: I had to watch my friends, people who can barely hold a sword, try to fight a pack of murderous zealots.
Alfira: All I could do was run.

Alfira: That means a lot, coming from you. You always seem to take everything in your stride.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: 'When the night is dark, stars shine brightest.' So keep on shining. It's going to be all right.
Alfira: 'Heart's Requiem', right? The hero survives a war and rebuilds her life - stronger than ever. A tale worth remembering - especially now.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus - I believe I mentioned him before. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.
Gale: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.
Gale: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: You 'think'? What happens if you fail?
Gale: Well, there'd be risk in such an endeavour, but only proportionate to the reward.
NodeContext: Doesn't want to get bogged down by doubts like these
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Don't dare to assume why I worship. Not all of us share such transactional relationships with our gods.
Gale: But do you not expect something in return for your devotion? Some favour, some stir of courage, some response?
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: Or to destroy the next wizard who attempts it. The attempt would kill you as it killed Karsus.
Gale: Do you think I had not considered that? I have no intention of repeating his folly.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Neither - I came here looking for a cure for my tadpole.
Vlaakith: And you just happened to STUMBLE on the Astral Prism?
NodeContext: completely incredulous
Vlaakith: Hmm. HMMMMM.
NodeContext: Scary and torn while she considers you
Vlaakith: At least you brought it back. It is a start.
Vlaakith: We will test you. To assess whether you deserve reward or punishment.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Player: I will do as you wish.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: I prefer a weapon to a stench, thanks.
Gandrel: Sharp steel is not proof against all the monsters of this world, my friend.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: It's a teahouse - hardly a lair.
Gandrel: A charming sight, to be sure. But the prettiest web still has a spider sitting at its centre.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: And are you fool enough?
Gandrel: Of course. I'm a hunter who lost his prey, and here I am seeking help from something worse.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: There's enough deception in this place - don't add to it.
Gandrel: It is not everyone who can see past her parlour tricks. As you wish - the truth is not mine to keep.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: We've met - he's not the type to come quietly.
Gandrel: You do know him? I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

Astarion: Morning. I hope last night's little unpleasantness hasn't left a bad taste in your-
Astarion: Well. I hope there are no bad feelings.
Player: You're lucky I didn't kill you.
Astarion: And you're lucky I'm not a 'true' vampire. Last night could have gone very differently if I'd magically summoned a pack of wolves.
Astarion: Alas, I'm just a spawn. All of the hunger, few of the powers.
Player: Pity. I thought you'd be more powerful.
Astarion: Perhaps I am. For two hundred years, the sun would have turned me to cinders. Now I stand here like it's nothing.
Astarion: Someone - or something - wants me alive. They've changed the rules.
Astarion: Standing in the sun, wading through a river, wandering into homes without an invitation - they're all perfectly mundane activities now.
Astarion: As for my other quirks - well, we can figure those out in time.
Player: If I can help, just ask. We're in this together.
Astarion: Oh you're such a sweetheart.
Astarion: I'm just glad you're being sensible about these revelations. I was worried people might turn up with torches and pitchforks.
Astarion: Although there's still time.
NodeContext: Looks over his shoulder, realising someone's approaching
Gale: So we're travelling with a vampire, are we?
Gale: A word of warning, Astarion: I taste absolutely awful. Keep your distance.
Player: I trust him. He won't hurt us.

Balthazar: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.

: False

Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.

Player: I'll see what I can do.

Karlach: InternalNodeContext: Character saw Astarion use his 'bite' ability on someone else (probably in combat, but not necessarily) and confronts him about being a vampire.
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Karlach: Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: You fight in the Blood War for Zariel. You'll bring the Blood War to the Coast.
Karlach: Yeah, I stowed away on a mind flayer ship so I could bring the war home. Makes perfect sense.
Karlach: If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that.
Karlach: Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Gale: Easy, Wyll. She's no devil. There's no fight to be had here.

Player: No. No second-guessing. The devil dies - now.

Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Give the book to Gale.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: The design for self-destruction, more like. Didn't this crown kill Karsus?
Gale: Not exactly. It was what he did with it that sealed his fate, and for a time, that of magic itself. The Crown was merely the means.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: To what end?
Gale: To every end you can imagine, and a thousand more beyond.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Mortals are far better guardians of their fates than the gods. We have more to lose.
Gale: Then you're already wiser than me. That's a lesson I've only recently learned.
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: And you believe yourself to be that successor?
Gale: Not until this moment, but I can't help beginning to see such a destiny unfold before me.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Gale: Thank you.
