Gale: There's that confidence I like.
Gale: I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening.
Gale: More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you.

Gale: Or perhaps more than you bargained for - full stop.
Gale: Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Shadowheart.
Gale: Indeed?
Gale: We shared a romantic moment of the mind while cloaked in the Weave, didn't we?
Gale: And I seem to recall a fond allusion to that moment afterwards.
Gale: Allow me to make the following proposition:
Gale: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen.
Gale: They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired.
Gale: The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself.
Gale: I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Let me stop you right there. That's not something I'm interested in.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: # Mizora's Exit sequence #
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Just what are you up to?
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Enough, Mizora. My father is dead. Say your piece.
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Remain silent.
Mizora: Yet no contract is ended without sacrifice, Wyll. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father dies by his enemy's hand, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Leave him dead. When the city's free, you can take his place.

Balthazar: The miserable worm tried to kill me, hoping to take all the glory of this mission for himself.
Balthazar: Dull, dull, dull. Nere was never cut out to be a True Soul - he's a very obedient corpse, though.

Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.

Player: I outmatch you in both brains and magic - you need me.
Player: It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Who are you?
Gandrel: Today? The same as you - a humble supplicant, come to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: It's a teahouse - hardly a lair.
Gandrel: A charming sight, to be sure. But the prettiest web still has a spider sitting at its centre.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: I think you're mistaken - this place looks innocent enough.
Gandrel: That would be nice. I'd welcome a proper cup of tea.
Gandrel: But I'm not wrong. Take her lightly, and she'll serve up your eyes for appetisers.
Gandrel: I'll eat them, too. I need her knowledge - the thing I hunt has gone to ground.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: There's enough deception in this place - don't add to it.
Gandrel: It is not everyone who can see past her parlour tricks. As you wish - the truth is not mine to keep.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You're wasting your time. Astarion's been dealt with.
Gandrel: You know him? Not too well, I think, if you believe he is so easily slain. He could be stalking your camp at this very moment.
Gandrel: Perhaps you could tell me where to look, and I could ensure peace of mind for us both?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

Vlaakith: Inquisitor W'wargaz was potent. We are impressed.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My Queen - shkath zai!
NodeContext: shkaath ZAI - for the honour!
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Lae'zel: The Deathless Queen has spoken. You will obey.
Player: Wave politely.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player waves politely at Vlaakith.
Vlaakith: Did your crèche teach you nothing?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, motions everyone present to rise.l Everyone rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face Lae'zel at their eye level.
Vlaakith: These attendants you keep - you taught them well. My child. My Lae'zel.
Lae'zel: Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. You know me.
Vlaakith: Urlon of K'liir speaks most highly. As did Al'chaia before him.
Vlaakith: You seek purity. I may yet grant it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: I didn't take the weapon from you, but I am returning it.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: You have ventured far from your kind's comforts to serve us.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Kill them.
Vlaakith: Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this -
Vlaakith: - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne.
Lae'zel: Choose. But know this: the cost of refusal is great.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.
Player: Can't you kill them yourself? I thought 'gods' were all-powerful.
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Lae'zel: Do not test her. She will be our ruin.
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

Gale: I finally have the tome I needed. Such knowledge - such power - contained in such a small object.
Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus - I believe I mentioned him before. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.
Gale: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.
Gale: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: Aren't you forgetting something? We have to hand the Crown to Raphael...
Gale: A situation I suggest we remedy with the utmost urgency.
Gale: I promise you - the power such an item would give us is worth transcending all nine Hells for. The heavens too, while we're at it.
NodeContext: Gleam in his eyes, excitement
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: And you think Mystra will let you do this?
Gale: I don't know. Ao does not look kindly on gods meddling in mortal affairs - she may have no choice but to stand by and let events unfold.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: And you believe yourself to be that successor?
Gale: Not until this moment, but I can't help beginning to see such a destiny unfold before me.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: What you're suggesting is blasphemy. You'd be wise to banish these notions from your head.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
Havkelaag: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment.
Havkelaag: Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: All right. How do I help?
Halsin: My thanks. If you prevail, I'll owe you the debt of a lifetime.
Halsin: It's too late to stop things from here - the goblins are already marching on the grove in force.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: Very well. I'll go rescue the grove.

Lord Enver Gortash: We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three.

Lord Enver Gortash: You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute.

Lord Enver Gortash: The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: # Mizora's Exit sequence #
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Please, introduce me to your friends.
Mizora: Feena, Cirrus. Arbiters for the Hells, exemplars of justice.
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Father is dead? Godsdamned devil. Why are you here?
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: What are you proposing?
Mizora: A life for a life. No contract is ended without sacrifice. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father dies by his enemy's hand, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Save your father, Wyll. The city will need him to help rebuild.

Klaus: Hello, hello, and welcome to the Circus of the Last Days - the finest extraplanar circus there is!
Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Player: Is now the time for a circus? The army of the Absolute is close.
Klaus: Well, when we zapped in, we didn't know there were religious zealots marching on the city. Slight inconvenience, that. But they're no threat to us.
Klaus: The Absolute's little murderers wouldn't dare.
Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!
Klaus: But enough of this - the circus is a place of joy and distraction! So come inside and forget your worries.
Player: All right - I'd like to enter the circus.
Klaus: Not a problem, dear patron! Benji just has to check if you're a vicious murderer. Benji!
Benji: *Sniff.* Huh. *Sniff.* *SNIFF.*
Benji: Urgh. Smells like a MUD FART.
Klaus: So, doesn't know the meaning of the word soap? Hmm. I don't fancy subjecting our patrons to such a stink.
Klaus: I'm afraid you'll have to move along - no circus for you.
Klaus: That's a first. Usually I'd allow you in, but in these times I can take no chances. Move along - no circus for you.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Who are you?
Gandrel: Today? The same as you - a humble supplicant, come to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Why would you assume that?
Gandrel: Because this is her domain. If you are here, it is because it suits her.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak plainly. What is she?
Gandrel: A powerful friend. A terrible foe. That, I cannot decide for you.
Gandrel: For my part - I need her knowledge. The thing I hunt has gone to ground.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Come now - I've almost certainly killed worse.
: True
Gandrel: I would not be so sure. But I won't keep the truth from you.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?

Gandrel: So you have met him. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist.
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

Lorroakan: Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books.

Lorroakan: Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?

Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.

Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.

Lorroakan: You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?

Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase.

Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.

Jaheira: Would you hand her over to have her wings pulled off by this self-inflated wretch?
Lorroakan: Good. Then you'll have no trouble fulfilling the contract to bring the Nightsong here.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: I prefer a weapon to a stench, thanks.
Gandrel: Sharp steel is not proof against all the monsters of this world, my friend.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Why would you assume that?
Gandrel: Because this is her domain. If you are here, it is because it suits her.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak for yourself - I got what I wanted.
Gandrel: So said the fish 'round the hook in its mouth.
Gandrel: But, one fool to another, I can't say I judge you. The thing I hunt has slipped away from me.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Your coyness is getting boring. Tell me.
: True
Gandrel: You take insult where none is intended, my friend. But fine - I won't add to it.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You can give up your hunt. Astarion's under my protection.

Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.

Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.

Alfira: Cal and Lia were dragged away, along with the others. Rolan isn't... taking it so well. None of us, to be honest.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Forgetfulness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: They need a better subject to practise on first. Not a student, but a master.
: True
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Gale: A beautiful night, don't you think? Nothing like a brush with destruction to make one appreciate the majesty of the celestial canvas.
Gale: It's a view I would once have shared with my companion. Though definitely unaccompanied by such revelry.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: I hope you aren't talking about Mystra again...
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be proud to see me keeping such fine company - the saviour of those poor tieflings, no less. And I've given her precious little to be proud of recently.
Gale: She has a good heart, and she would recognise the same in your actions here. I'm sure she'd approve of me lending myself to your efforts.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: She must be very smart, to have done all that.
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. Something in the way you roll your eyes when I speak...
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: You don't have any friends?
Gale: Sadly not. If I'm being entirely honest, my social circle is rather small. More of a dot. Or a pinhead.
Gale: I've got aquaintances, certainly. Plenty of colleagues. But friends? Those are precious indeed.
Gale: I hope, though we've only known each other for a short time, I might be able to count you among that number?
Player: Friends with the mighty Gale of Waterdeep? I'd be honoured.
Gale: I'm glad. To know you enjoy my company is, well, it's rather wonderful actually. I'd be loathe to waste the time of someone who's become rather important to me.
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: The feeling's mutual - you're a wonderful friend. Though usually more... erudite.

Narrator: *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.*

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: A githyanki? What are you doing down here?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that!
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Who was your father?
Ptaris: Havkelaag. He brought me from the shell. Raised me quickly. Taught me to be good. But he failed me.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: Not especially.
Ptaris: At least you are honest.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion

Lae'zel: Vlaakith. My Queen.
NodeContext: With reverence.
Vlaakith: You carry a ghaik parasite. You harbour the Heretic Prince. Yet so blind is your faith that you still call me Queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The hologram flickers. Its power is waning.
Vlaakith: There's little time. I will speak, and you will listen.
Vlaakith: We are githyanki. We move mountains, we snuff out stars, we shake the planes.
Vlaakith: The Heretic Prince would shatter us in an instant. The Great Dominion, shrunk to the head of a pin.
Narrator: *Can this be true? Is the githyanki prince really a threat to his own people or simply a challenge to Vlaakith's rule?*
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The hologram flickers once more.
Vlaakith: Return to the Astral Prism. Slay Orpheus the pretender.
Vlaakith: Serve me and I will ascend you. You will be no mere warrior, nor kith'rak. You will be Baht t'Vlaakith.
Vlaakith: Commander of Dragons. My only, my Chosen.
Vlaakith: A final chance. Kneel before me. Make your promise.
Narrator: *Lae'zel's thoughts become yours. The sight of Orpheus looms over her mind; Voss' words echo within it. She means to forever turn her back on Vlaakith.*
Player: Stand your ground. Don't fall for Vlaakith's lies.
Vlaakith: Shka'keth! You speak against the Eternal Queen?
Lae'zel: I gave you my faith, and you called me traitor. I gave you my life, and you ordered your knights to hunt me.
Lae'zel: I have witnessed too much, and you have given me too little. Finally, I can see.
Lae'zel: Orpheus will live, and I will hear his creed. This is my word.
Vlaakith: Your word is nothing. You are nothing.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Hologram flickers urgently
Vlaakith: The kith'raki will bring you. I will tear your flesh from your bones and devour your skull's marrow while you beg for death.
Vlaakith: I will consume you. I will unmake you!

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?
Malus Thorm: The crux of our worship.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: Who are you?
Gandrel: Today? The same as you - a humble supplicant, come to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Not at all. I was invited for tea.
Gandrel: Of course - as the spider invites the fly. You need something, I expect. And she sensed it.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.

Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.

Zevlor: We'd need an army of our own to escort us safely to Baldur's Gate, and while I don't doubt your abilities... you're no army.
Zevlor: There may be a way though. Goblins are ill-disciplined - it's unlike them to organise so cleverly.

Zevlor: Somebody must be leading them, bringing discipline to their ranks. Take out that leadership, and they'll scatter.
Zevlor: The Blade of Frontiers has done what he can to help us prepare for the journey, and we're grateful, but it'll be a short journey if the goblins still own the roads.
Wyll: By the Triad, there is only one correct answer. Refuse him, and we sentence these people to die.
Player: That depends - can you pay me?
Zevlor: I suppose so. We don't have much. But we'll scrape together whatever we can.
Player: Don't bother. I'll do what I can.

Kith'rak Voss: What easy prey you make, walking right within my blade's embrace.
Kith'rak Voss: These creatures are so simple to ensnare, Baretha. You mewl too much about your task.
Sarth Baretha: Forgiveness, Kith'rak.
Kith'rak Voss: And as for you, tell me - why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Player: You would've done so already if you didn't want something from me first.
: True
Kith'rak Voss: Perceptive, for such an inferior creature.
Kith'rak Voss: For you to keep sucking air, it is necessary for you to tell me something of worth.
Kith'rak Voss: A vessel fell from the sky. We seek a precious weapon that was taken from it.

Narrator: *You realise that the weapon Voss speaks of is the gith artefact you carry. You cannot let him discover it - no matter what.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the giths' suspicion cannot be aroused. They cannot discover that the weapon they seek is right within their grasp.*
Kith'rak Voss: Help us find it and I will leave your blood beneath your skin, unspilled.
Shadowheart: Don't help them. Don't tell them a thing. We're dead if you do.
Player: You'll need to start from the beginning - what is this weapon you're after?
Kith'rak Voss: Do not speak. Your bleating offends my ears. Just stand still...
Narrator: *He begins to move his hand in a quick flurry of gestures.*
NodeContext: Narration.
Player: Silently interpret the meaning of the gestures.
: True
Narrator: *You realise he's casting Detect Thoughts.*
Player: Resist the probing into your mind.
: True
Kith'rak Voss: Bah! Nothing even approaching a useful thought in that skull. I ought to just kill you...
Player: Give it a try. I'm hungry for a little fun.
: True
Kith'rak Voss: So bold in the face of death... Perhaps you may live after all.
Kith'rak Voss: Better to let stronger blood thrive. It can give rise to worthier foes and hardier slaves. Don't disappoint me.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am a scholar, this is true - just not in the study of torture.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Booyahg Piddle: Here - help us out. Sez here that 'goblinoids are obstreperous and malodorous'. What's that mean?
Player: It means 'mephitic and vociferous.'
Booyahg Piddle: Oh... Of course. Yeah, I'd have 'ad said that. Bit wordy though, innit?
Booyahg Piddle: Still - only other stuff to read around 'ere is the filth Klagga scrawls in the latrines.
Player: Where did you find that?
Booyahg Piddle: Belonged to some bloke that showed up here askin' questions. Bold as a bugbear, he woz!
Booyahg Piddle: Said he's writin' a book about the Absolute. Lads didn't like that - said he was a spy or some such...
Booyahg Piddle: ... think they've locked 'im in the cells already.
Booyahg Piddle: ... that's 'im, at the party, warblin' away.
Booyahg Piddle: I had a good chinwag with him though. Interestin' bloke.
Player: Have you met any other interesting people? A druid, perhaps?
Booyahg Piddle: There were some troublemakers, but they're either dead or wishing they were. Don't know if there was a druid though.
Booyahg Piddle: He's probably down in the pens, fattenin' up the worgs like all the rest.
Player: This writer - will he be fed to the worgs too?
Booyahg Piddle: Nah. We're keepin' him as our own little plaything, so long as he don't ask any more awkward questions.
Player: Could I see his manuscript?
Booyahg Piddle: I ain't finished with it! There's enough readin' here to last me a lifetime.
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Player: Your lifetime gets shorter every second you keep that book.
: True
Booyahg Piddle: Bloody hell - an' people say goblins are savage.

Fezzerk: Look what we got here - another little birdie wantin' to fly!
NodeContext: Cruel bravado.The goblin sees the player approach and boldly announces it to his cronies - he thinks some fresh victims have just turned up.
Fezzerk: Yehehueh! Flap those wings some more, an' I'll feed you a worm!
NodeContext: Greatly amused. A schoolyard bully tormenting the little kid. Projecting his voice a little (Fezzerk calls out to taunt his deep gnome prisoner, who rotates on the sail of a windmill a short-moderate distance off.)
'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
Fezzerk: An' you - hope you got a stomach fer heights!
NodeContext: Confident, unpleasant. Turning his attention to the player to deliver a threat.
Player: I'm not looking for trouble - just want to pass by.
Fezzerk: Heh, funny. That's what our birdie wanted.
Barcus Wroot: ...Release me this instant, you beasts!
NodeContext: Panicked, angry. Issuing an ultimatum even though he has no means of following through on it.
Fezzerk: 'Less you wanna join him up there, you'd best pay the toll.
NodeContext: Confident, threatening. Thinks he holds all the cards in a one-sided negotiation.

Fezzerk: I said we're leaving!
Fezzerk: Apologies, your grace. We didn't mean to doubt a True Soul. We'll be off.

Rugan: Thank the gods that's over. Wish you'd been with us when the beasts attacked on the road.

Rugan: Might have been more survivors... I don't suppose you saw any of my crew alive out there?
Rugan: Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: No. It's a grim sight.
Rugan: This whole journey's been one grim sight after another. Gnolls, goblins... drow.
Rugan: Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Maybe I should come - see you don't get waylaid again.
Rugan: Thanks. But that won't be necessary. We'll find help at Waukeen's Rest.
Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.
Rugan: You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only.
Rugan: Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: Read his thoughts.
: True
Rugan: Shame we lost so many agents. But the chest is all that matters - Zarys'd have our hides if we lost it.

Rugan: He gets his shiny baubles, we get a handful of Tarenths.
: True
Narrator: *Tarenths are the currency of a merchant network called the Zhentarim. Led by the mysterious Pereghost of Darkhold, their dealings are far from scrupulous.*
Player: You're Zhentarim. Your people don't deal in 'baubles'.
Rugan: You know who we are - very clever. Then you probably also know it's not smart to interfere with Zhent business.
Rugan: This is the point when a clever operator like you accepts my gratitude and walks away.
Player: Enough talking. I'll have that cargo, or I'll have your head.
Player: No. This is the point where I stop asking, and start cutting.
: False
Rugan: My associates will do worse to me than you ever could.
Rugan: Let's go our separate ways, and be thankful we're all in one piece.
Player: You had your chance. Either way, that cargo's mine.

Gale: A beautiful night, don't you think? Nothing like a brush with destruction to make one appreciate the majesty of the celestial canvas.
Gale: It's a view I would once have shared with my companion. Though definitely unaccompanied by such revelry.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: I hope you aren't talking about Mystra again...
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be proud to see me keeping such fine company - the saviour of those poor tieflings, no less. And I've given her precious little to be proud of recently.
Gale: She has a good heart, and she would recognise the same in your actions here. I'm sure she'd approve of me lending myself to your efforts.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: She must be very smart, to have done all that.
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. An expression you both share - when she gives in to her more feline qualities, a mouse trapped beneath her paw...
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: She sounds like a fine animal. One I'd be honoured to know.
Gale: She'll love you. So long as you don't rub her belly. She hates it when anyone does that.
Player: She sounds great. But I was hoping I meant more to you than an animal companion...
Gale: I assure you, were you to meet Tara you would see the comparison for the flattery it is. But perhaps that's not a point worth labouring further.
Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: Being mentioned in the same breath as your pet isn't the compliment you think it is...
Gale: Then let me say it more plainly -
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: The feeling's mutual - you're a wonderful friend. Though usually more... erudite.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kneels, head bowed, solemn, appropriate. Vlaakith offers something resembling a smile, and gestures for the player to rise. The player rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Yours? I found it. The artefact is mine.
Wyll: By the Nine Hells - she's not going to like that.
Vlaakith: To own something is to know it. You know NOTHING of what you carry.

Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Vlaakith: You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.
Player: So the dream visitor is inside the artefact... I can't kill them. They protect me from the Absolute.
Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO.
Vlaakith: I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,
Player: No. In fact, maybe I'll free the one inside.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Our time has come, son. Together, we will usher in a new dawn.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.

Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.

Player: Forgetfulness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: It's no coincidence that you found me here, I'll wager? You're after a cure for this parasite.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you.
Halsin: I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem...
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: I'll deal with this. You get to safety.
Halsin: There is no safety. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.
Player: Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins.
Halsin: If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Come with me.
Halsin: So be it. May Silvanus lend us nature's fury.

Rugan: By the gods, you're a sweet sight.
Rugan: Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: No. It's a grim sight.
Rugan: This whole journey's been one grim sight after another. Gnolls, goblins... drow.
Rugan: Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Maybe I should come - see you don't get waylaid again.
Rugan: Thanks. But that won't be necessary. We'll find help at Waukeen's Rest.
Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.
Rugan: You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only.
Rugan: Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: What's in the chest? Your cargo?
Rugan: Aye. The whole reason we're in this mess. Trinkets for some rich tosser in Baldur's Gate.
Rugan: He gets his shiny baubles, we get a handful of Tarenths.
: True
Narrator: *Tarenths are the currency of the Zhentarim - a network of merchants and mercenaries with few scruples.*
Narrator: *Tarenths are the currency of a merchant network called the Zhentarim. Led by the mysterious Pereghost of Darkhold, their dealings are far from scrupulous.*
Player: You're Zhentarim. Your people don't deal in 'baubles'.
Rugan: You know who we are - very clever. Then you probably also know it's not smart to interfere with Zhent business.
Rugan: This is the point when a clever operator like you accepts my gratitude and walks away.
Player: You're missing a golden opportunity. Report the cargo lost - and we can sell it ourselves.
Player: You'll find I'm very persuasive. We can make much more coin than you would with your employers.
: True
Rugan: I like the way you think. Didn't expect to turn this horrorshow to my advantage... but why not?
Rugan: The chest's all yours. Damn thing's sealed tighter than a Duke's pursestrings, so there's no point in trying to open it.
Rugan: I know a fence in Baldur's Gate who'll take it off your hands. Nobody will be the wiser.
Rugan: Don't try to cut me out of the deal though. The Black Network has eyes and blades everywhere.
Rugan: Crafty swine like you could make a name for yourself in the Zhentarim. Make sure to drop by our hideout.
Rugan: Pass phrase at the door is 'little serpent, long shadow'. I'll tell my associates to expect you.
Player: I already met your friends - we didn't get along too well.
Rugan: And yet here you are. There's not many cause trouble in a Zhent hideout and walk away.
Rugan: I'd rather walk away too. So let's say our goodbyes, and speak no more of it.
Player: Cargo's mine now. Goodbye.
Player: You can leave - but your cargo stays.

Mizora: Still yourself, pup. Not every death is forever.
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.

Player: Remain silent.
Mizora: Yet no contract is ended without sacrifice, Wyll. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Save your father, Wyll. The city will need him to help rebuild.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?
Malus Thorm: The crux of our worship.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Darkness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Secrecy.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: I have read your treatise. Initiate the final lesson, or die by my hand.
: True
Malus Thorm: The final lesson. Yes. For to teach absence, one must become absent.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Havkelaag: I say - that wasn't a githyanki egg you were fiddling around with, was it?
Havkelaag: How would you like to sell it to the Society of Brilliance? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Lorroakan: You have a job to do. So do it - quickly.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap.
Lorroakan: Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books.
Lorroakan: But enough of dusty history - I look to the future.
Lorroakan: You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?
Lorroakan: 'She'. Then you do know her. You've been to Shar's temple. To the Shadowfell. You've looked upon the Nightsong's face.
Lorroakan: Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?

Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase.
Lorroakan: Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him.
Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.

Lorroakan: I serve no god but that which stares back at me in the mirror.
Lorroakan: The Nightsong will be put to a grand purpose: equalising man and god. Whoever helps me attain that which I seek will be greatly rewarded.

Lorroakan: I intend to achieve greatness. And I intend to do it for a long, long, long time.
Lorroakan: When I succeed, I may look favourably upon you. If you are a friend along the way, that is.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: You're a monster hunter? Not what I imagined.
Gandrel: Hah. Perhaps that is why I have survived so long where more fearsome peers have not.
Gandrel: You would be wise to look past the seeming of things, if you intend to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Are you talking about Auntie Ethel?
Gandrel: A gentle name. But I speak of her nature.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak plainly. What is she?
Gandrel: A powerful friend. A terrible foe. That, I cannot decide for you.
Gandrel: For my part - I need her knowledge. The thing I hunt has gone to ground.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Maybe I can help with your hunt.
: True
Gandrel: No. This duty is mine alone. But for such an offer, an answer at least is owed.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You're wasting your time. Astarion's been dealt with.
Gandrel: You know him? Not too well, I think, if you believe he is so easily slain. He could be stalking your camp at this very moment.
Gandrel: Perhaps you could tell me where to look, and I could ensure peace of mind for us both?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: I'm not going to help you find him. Back off.
